cameraPermissionMsg: TutorSudoku needs access to your camera to scan puzzles.
cameraPermissionRequired: Camera permission is required to scan Sudoku puzzles.
noSudokuFoundMsg: We couldn't recognize enough numbers. Try to capture a clear, close-up image of the grid.
scanPuzzleDesc: Capture a Sudoku to solve instantly
verifyPuzzleDesc: Check if the captured numbers are correct. Tap a cell to edit.
learnSudokuDesc: Master techniques from beginner to pro
tech_nakedSingle_desc: When a cell has only one possible candidate remaining, that number implies the solution for that cell.
tech_nakedSingle_example: If a cell can only be '5' because 1-4 and 6-9 are already in the row, col, or box, fill it in!
tech_hiddenSingle_desc: When a number can only go in one specific cell within a row, column, or box, even if that cell has other candidates.
tech_hiddenSingle_example: In a 3x3 box, if the number '7' can only be placed in the top-right cell (because other cells are blocked), it must go there.
tech_lockedCandidates_desc: If a candidate number is restricted to a single row or column within a 3x3 box, you can eliminate that number from the rest of that row or column outside the box.
tech_lockedCandidates_example: If '3's in Box 1 are only in the top row, then no other cell in the top row (in Box 2 or 3) can be a 3.
tech_nakedPairs_desc: If two cells in a unit (row/col/box) contain exactly the same two candidates (e.g., 2 & 7), those numbers must be in those two cells. You can remove them from all other cells in that unit.
tech_nakedPairs_example: Cells A1 and A2 both have candidates {2, 7}. No other cell in Row A can have 2 or 7.
tech_hiddenPairs_desc: If two numbers appear ONLY in two specific cells within a unit (row/col/box), they form a Hidden Pair. Even if those cells have other notes, they MUST be the pair.
tech_hiddenPairs_example: In a row, if '3' and '9' only appear in the 1st and 5th cells, those cells must be 3 and 9. Remove all other notes from them.
tech_nakedTriples_desc: Three cells in a unit share three candidates among them (e.g., {1,2}, {2,3}, {1,3} or {1,2,3}). These three numbers must go in these three cells.
tech_nakedTriples_example: In a box, three cells have notes {1,2}, {2,3}, and {1,3}. No other cell in that box can contain 1, 2, or 3.
tech_hiddenTriples_desc: If three numbers appear ONLY in three specific cells within a unit, they form a Hidden Triple. Those cells are reserved for these three numbers.
tech_hiddenTriples_example: If 4, 5, and 6 only appear in three specific cells of a column, remove all unrelated notes from those cells.
tech_xWing_desc: When a number appears in exactly two spots in two different rows, and these spots align in columns, it forms a rectangle. You can eliminate that number from the rest of the columns.
tech_xWing_example: If '7' is in only cols 2 and 8 for both Row A and Row C, then '7' cannot appear in cols 2 and 8 in any other row.
tech_yWing_desc: A pivot cell connects to two 'pincers'. If the pivot is XY, and pincers are YZ and XZ, any cell seeing both pincers cannot contain Z.
tech_yWing_example: Pivot {1,2}, Pincer A {2,3}, Pincer B {1,3}. Any cell seeing both Pincer A and B cannot be '3'.
tech_swordfish_desc: Like an X-Wing but with three rows and three columns. If a number appears in only 2-3 specific columns across three rows, it forms a pattern eliminating that number from those columns elsewhere.
tech_swordfish_example: A '5' restricted to cols 1, 5, 9 in rows A, D, F. Eliminates '5' from cols 1, 5, 9 in all other rows.
tut_naked-single-1_step_0: Let's look at the highlighted cell on this board.
tut_naked-single-1_step_1: Considering its row, column, and box, the only number that can be placed here is 2. This is a Naked Single.
tut_hidden-single-1_step_0: Let's look at the highlighted cell on this board.
tut_hidden-single-1_step_1: Looking at the first and second columns, the number 1 can only go in this cell. This is a Hidden Single.
tut_locked-1_step_0: Let's look at the top-left box. All cells where the number 4 can be placed are located in the 1st column.
tut_locked-1_step_1: Therefore, the number 4 cannot appear in any other cell in the 1st column, and we can eliminate 4 from those cells. This is a Locked Candidates.
tut_naked-pair-1_step_0: Looking at the highlighted cells, the pair {7,9} can only go into these cells within this box. So, if one of these cells is 7, the other must be 9.
tut_naked-pair-1_step_1: Therefore, we can eliminate the numbers 7 and 9 from other cells in this box. This is a Naked Pair.
tut_hidden-pair-1_step_0: Looking at the box containing the highlighted cells and their notes, the pair {2,6} can only be placed in these cells.
tut_hidden-pair-1_step_1: Therefore, we can eliminate all other notes from these cells.
tut_naked-triple-1_step_0: These 3 highlighted cells can respectively take the pairs {1,5}, {1,8}, and {5,8}. For example, if the left highlighted cell is 1, the middle cell must be 8, and the right cell must be 5.
tut_naked-triple-1_step_1: Consequently, we can eliminate the notes {1,5,8} from other cells in this box. This is a Naked Triple.
tut_hidden-triple-1_step_0: Considering the box and notes where the highlighted cells are located, the triple {5,6,7} can only be placed in these highlighted cells. Any other notes in these highlighted cells are irrelevant.
tut_hidden-triple-1_step_1: Therefore, we can delete the other notes from these highlighted cells. This is a Hidden Triple.
tut_x-wing-1_step_0: Let's observe rows 3 and 5. In both rows, there are only 2 cells where the number 4 can be placed. Also, these cells share the same columns. Thus, the 4s must be placed diagonally.
tut_x-wing-1_step_1: Therefore, we can delete the 4 notes from other cells in the columns where these cells are located. This is an X-Wing.
tut_y-wing-1_step_0: First, we must find a cell with 2 notes. This will be our pivot cell (Row:1, Column:2). Then, we need to find 2 more cells in the same row or column as the pivot, also containing 2 notes. These cells will be our pincer cells. One note in each pincer must match a note in the pivot, and the other notes in the pincers must match each other.
tut_y-wing-1_step_1: Now let's look at this highlighted cell where the pincers intersect. If this cell contains the same note shared by the pincers, we can eliminate it. In this example, we can eliminate the note 4 from this cell.
tut_swordfish-1_step_0: Let's pay attention to columns 1, 2, and 9 and the highlighted cells. On this board, the number 6 will be our 'fish number'. Evaluating the highlighted cells by their columns, they are perfectly aligned. The number 6 appears in column 1 at rows 6 and 9; in column 2 at rows 1 and 9; and in column 9 at rows 1 and 6. Thus, there are 2 options for the number 6:
tut_swordfish-1_step_3: Considering both options, we can eliminate the note 6 from all other cells in columns 1, 2, and 9. This is a Swordfish.
hint_nakedSingle:
ðŸ’¡ Naked Single

This cell (Row {{row}}, Col {{col}}) can ONLY be **{{val}}**.

All other numbers blocked by Row, Column, or Box.
hint_hiddenSingleRow:
ðŸ’¡ Hidden Single (Row)

Row {{row}}, Column {{col}} is the ONLY place in this row for **{{val}}**.
hint_hiddenSingleCol:
ðŸ’¡ Hidden Single (Col)

Row {{row}}, Column {{col}} is the ONLY place in this column for **{{val}}**.
hint_lockedCandidatePointingRow:
ðŸ’¡ Locked Candidate (Pointing)

Look at Box {{box}}. The number {{val}} is restricted to Row {{row}}. Even though we don't know exactly where it goes in the box yet, we know it MUST be in this row.

Therefore, you can remove {{val}} from the rest of Row {{row}}.
hint_lockedCandidatePointingCol:
ðŸ’¡ Locked Candidate (Pointing)

Look at Box {{box}}. The number {{val}} is restricted to Column {{col}}. We know it MUST be in this column within the box.

Therefore, you can remove {{val}} from the rest of Column {{col}}.
hint_nakedPairRow:
ðŸ’¡ Naked Pair

Look at Row {{row}}. The cells at Column {{col1}} and Column {{col2}} contain only the candidates [{{candidates}}].

This means one of them must be {{val1}} and the other {{val2}}. No other cell in this row can contain these numbers. You can eliminate them from other cells in this row!
hint_nakedPairCol:
ðŸ’¡ Naked Pair

Look at Column {{col}}. A Naked Pair [{{candidates}}] exists.

Since these two cells must containing [{{candidates}}], these numbers cannot appear elsewhere in this column.
hint_noMove:
ðŸ¤” No obvious moves found.

The board might be very hard or require trying advanced elimination techniques!
conflict_row:
The number {{val}} already exists in specific row (Line {{row}}).
Sudoku rules state that each number 1-9 must appear exactly once in each row.
conflict_col:
The number {{val}} already exists in this column (Column {{col}}).
Each number must be unique within its vertical column.
conflict_box:
The number {{val}} is already in this 3x3 block.
Remember, each 3x3 grid must contain unique numbers from 1 to 9.
